entries.content: When a prospect says 'send me an email', the core goal is to understand *why* they are asking for an email.
Acknowledge the email request: "Totally fair, I can certainly do that."
Probe what specific information is needed for the email: "Just so I can make sure I don't send you a novel, what specifically would you want to see?"
Offer a short conversation instead of guessing email content: "Instead of me trying to guess what to send, how about I take 30 seconds right now?"
Frame the 'send me an email' request as potentially indicating the prospect is unsure of relevance.
Directly ask if the email request is about relevance or more information: "Are you not sure this is relevant, or you just want to learn more?"
Use an alternative probing structure for the email request: "When people ask for an email, usually one of two things is happening..."
entries.notes: Implies explaining the 'two things', typically relevance or needing detail for later.

entries.content: Use probing questions after an email request to determine the true objection or level of interest.
